newsitem.title: ALBANIA: Albania awaits exiled king as Italian troops land.
newsitem.headline: Albania awaits exiled king as Italian troops land.

text.p: Albanians awaited on Saturday the arrival of their exiled king, who was expected to appeal for an end to violence in the lawless Balkan state after the first contingent of a multinational security force arrived.

Guri Durollari of the Legality Movement Party said King Leka I had received the approval of the government to return home and would arrive at Tirana airport at 1 p.m. (1100 GMT) on a private plane from exile in South Africa.
"He will call on Albanians to put an end to violence and to put their guns away," Durollari told Reuters.

King Leka, 58, who was only a few days old when his father, King Zog, fled the country with his family in 1939, would call for a referendum to let Albanians decide whether or not to restore the monarchy, Durollari said.
"He is here to settle. He is here to stay," he added.

Leka, tall and bespectacled, only once tried to visit Albania, in 1993. He was unceremoniously bundled back onto a plane within 24 hours on the grounds that his passport marked "Kingdom of Albania" was invalid.
Durollari said President Sali Berisha had reiterated his approval of Leka's visit during a meeting in Tirana on Friday.

About 70 Italian soldiers arrived in Albania on Friday to prepare for the landing from Monday of a 6,000-strong multinational force that aims to protect the distribution of food and medicines to Albanians after weeks of near-anarchy.
Albanians greeted their arrival with indifference.
Twenty beaming Italian soldiers marched onto a pier in the western port of Durres beginning a mission marking the first time Italy had led a multinational force in post-war history.

"Our mission does not rule out risks, but we hope the Albanian people will understand that we are here to help them," said Colonel Enrico Nardi, commander of the Italian unit in Durres, 40 km (25 miles) west of Tirana.
Four Lockheed C130 Hercules aircraft carrying more than 50 paratroopers arrived at Tirana's airport in the morning.
As well as the Italians, soldiers from France, Spain, Romania, Turkey and Greece are coming to Albania to help safeguard deliveries of emergency food and medical supplies.
The armed lawlessness in which more than 200 people were killed and 700 wounded since several fraudulent get-rich-quick investment schemes collapsed claimed more casualties on Friday.
A 16-year-old boy was killed in a village near the southern town of Vlore when a grenade he was playing with exploded, police said. A 15-year-old boy was seriously injured.
Several people were hurt in a gun battle between police and a gang in Fier, 110 km (70 miles) south of Tirana, police said.
Two armed men stormed a town meeting and tried to take control, they said. The two were backed by about 15 others firing rifles into the sky.
After a skirmish with police, the gang commandeered a police armoured personnel carrier (APC) and escaped.

In the northern town of Shkoder, hospital workers demonstrated on Friday against the violence after two doctors were shot and wounded in a daylight attack on the hospital. The reasons for the attack were unclear.
Albanian state television showed graphic images of doctors operating on a colleague.
On Friday night, a regular crackle of automatic rifle fire rang out in Tirana.
In Durres, dozens of journalists greeted the Italian soldiers, but only a handful of Albanians were on hand.
"All this for only 20 soldiers?" asked 50-year-old port worker Besim, watching three dozen newsmen scramble to interview them. "There are more journalists than soldiers."
The advance unit landing at Tirana airport included special forces to secure the perimeter and specialists to ensure the airport could operate round the clock.
